description: From Middle English guise, gise, gyse, from Old French guisse, guise, vise (“guise, manner, way”), from Old Frankish *wīsa (“manner, way, fashion”), from Proto-Germanic *wīsǭ (“manner, way”), from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (“to see, view, behold, perceive”). Cognate with Old High German wīsa (“way, manner”), Old English wīse (“way, manner”), Dutch wijze (“way, manner”). More at wise.

entries.meaning: Customary way of speaking or acting; fashion, manner, practice (often used formerly in such phrases as "at his own guise"; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself.)
examples: dialecticians and sophists assume the same guise as the philosopher

entries.meaning: External appearance in manner or dress; appropriate indication or expression; garb; shape.

verbs.description: guise (third-person singular simple present guises, present participle guising, simple past and past participle guised)

entries.meaning: (archaic, intransitive) To act as a guiser; to go dressed up in a parade etc.
